case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 2184-2195 of 1969, 498 to 502 of 1970, 884 to 885 of 1971

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2184-2195 of 1969, 498 to 502 of 1970, and 884 to 885 of 1971 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 21842195 of 1969, 498 to 502 of 1970 884 to 885 of 1971. 1020 Civil Appeals Nos. 2184-2195 of 1969 and 498 to 502 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeals by certificate from judgment and order dated March 25, 1969 of Madras High Court in W.P. Nos. 4161-4164, 4246-4249 of 1965 and others.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated March 25, 1969 of the Madras High Court in W.P. Nos. 4161- 4164 4246-4249 of 1965 and Writ Petitions Nos. 198 199 and T. C. Nos. 227 and 228 of 1967

facts.text: Appeals by certificate from judgment dated March 2, 1970 of Madras High Court in Tax Case Nos. 21 and 22 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: and Civil Appeals Nos. 884 to 885 of 1971. Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated March 2, 1970 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case Nos. 21 and 22 of 1970.

facts.text: The material facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HEGDE, J. These appeals by certificate can be disposed of by one judgment. They raise common questions of law. The material facts are number, in dispute.

facts.text: Producers supplied cement to State Trading Corporation or its agents in gunny bags pursuant to Government directions.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeals Nos. 498,499 to 502 of 1970, the principal question of law that arises for decision is whether the producers who supplied the cement to the State Trading Corporation or its agents in gunny bags in pursuance of the directions given by the Government

facts.text: High Court decided questions in favour of the assessees; State of Tamil Nadu appealed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has decided both these questions in favour of the assessees. Aggrieved by that decision, the State of Tamil Nadu has come up in appeal.

facts.text: Supply of cement not considered sales under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959 due to Cement Control Order, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Taking first the case of the transactions between the producers and the State Trading Corporation, there is numberdispute that so far as the supply of cement is concerned, the same cannot be considered as sales within the meaning of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959 in view of the Cement Control Order, 1958.

facts.text: Relevant assessment years are 1959-60, 1960-1961, and 1961-1962.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant assessment years with which we are concerned in these appeals are assessment years 1959-60, 1960-1961 and 1961- 1962.

facts.text: Central Government order dated March 26, 1959 fixed packing charges for cement at Rs. 11.54 per ton in new gunny bags for April 1 to June 30, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the Central Government by its order dated March 26, 1959 informed all, concerned thus Packing charges for cement for period commencing to First April to Thirtieth June Nineteen Fifty nine will be Rupees Eleven Decimal five four per ton in New Gunny Bags.

facts.text: Central Government order dated June 24, 1959 fixed packing charges at Rs. 11.04 per ton for July 1 to September 30, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Again by its order dated June 24, 1959, it stipulated that the packing charges for cement for the period commencing 1st July to 30th September 1959 will be Rs. 11.04 per ton, in new gunny bags.

facts.text: Central Government letter dated December 26, 1959 informed State Trading Corporation of acceptance of Tariff Commission's recommendations on packing charges.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government by its letter dated December 26, 1959 informed the Staff Trading Corporation that it has accepted the Tariff Commissions recommendations in respect of the fixation of the packing char-es

facts.text: Central Government telegram dated February 17, 1961 fixed packing charges at Rs. 17 per ton under clause 6(4) of Cement Control Order, 1958 effective from February 20 to March 31, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: By its telegram dated February 17, 1961, the Central Government informed all the State Governments that having regard to the prevailing jute bag price, the Government was pleased to fix under clause 6 4  of the Cement Control Order, 1958 the charges for packing cement

facts.text: Learned Advocate-General of Tamil Nadu contended that Central Government fixed only maximum price of gunny bags under cl. 6(4).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate-General of Tamil Nadu contended that the Central Government under cl. 6 4  of the Cement Control Order, 1958 could have fixed only the maximum price of gunny bags and not the actual price

facts.text: This contention was not taken in High Court nor in appeal memo.

anchor.surface_text: This contention has not been taken in the High Court nor in the appeal memo. The Central Government has not put in its appearance in this Court.

facts.text: Rule 6(f) of rules under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959 stood as specified until September 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Now coming to the contention raised in the other appeals which also arises in some of the appeals earlier considered, it relates to the interpretation of rule 6 f  of the rules framed under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959. That rule as it stood upto September 1 963 read thus

facts.text: Rule 6(f) recast on September 27, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On September 27, 1 963, this rule was recast thus All amounts falling under the following three heads, when specified and charged for by the dealer separately,

facts.text: Rule 6(f) recast again on March 9, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: This rule was again recast on March 9, 1964. The rule as refrained reads thus 10 2 3 All amounts falling under the following three heads

facts.text: Some appeals relate to assessment years 1962-63 and 1963-64.

anchor.surface_text: In the above group of appeals, some relate to the assessment years 1962-63, and 1963-64.

facts.text: Price of packing materials was separately charged in the bills.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the price of the packing materials was separately charged in the bills issued.

facts.text: New contention raised at hearing regarding exemption under Central Sales Tax Act due to 1969 amendments with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing a new contention was sought to be raised by Mr. S. T. Desai. He sought to urge that the exemption given for packing material must be held to be not available in respect of the cases arising under the Central Sales Act

arguments.claim: Government orders fixed actual price of gunny bags under cl. 6(4), hence price controlled

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the Central Government by its order dated March 26, 1959 informed all, companycerned thus Packing charges for cement for period companymencing to First April to Thirtieth June Nineteen Fifty nine will be Rupees Eleven Decimal five four per ton in New Gunny Bags. Again by its order dated June 24, 1959, it stipulated that the packing charges for cement for the period companymencing 1st July to 30th September 1959 will be Rs. 11.04 per ton, in new gunny bags.

arguments.claim: Rule 6(f) as stood till Sep 1963 exempts only service charges for packing, not cost of packing material

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. T. Desai, learned Counsel appearing for the State of Tamil Nadu in this group of appeals companytended that the rule as it stood till September 1963, merely provided for exemption of service charges for packing and number the companyt of packing material. It is number disputed that the price of the packing materials was separately charged in the bills issued.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was recast thus All amounts falling under the following three heads, when specified and charged for by the dealer separately, without including them

arguments.court_reasoning: Overlooked earlier Madras HC decision in State of Madras In re holding identical rule exempts material cost too; charges for packing include material and labour; later recasts clarify intention

arguments.claim: Damodaran Chettiar case supports that price of packing material not covered by Rule 6(f)

anchor.surface_text: In support of his companytention that price of packing material is number companyered by the rule in question, Mr. Desai relied on the decision of the Madras High Court in State of Madras and Ors. v. K. Damodaran Chettiar Co.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was recast thus All amounts falling under the following three heads, when specified and charged for by the dealer separately, without including them

arguments.court_reasoning: Damodaran overlooked earlier decision; we agree with earlier view

arguments.claim: Rule 6(f) exempts price of packing material as well as labour; 'charges for packing' include both; refers to earlier Madras HC in State of Madras In re

anchor.surface_text: In that case Rajagopalan and Rajagopala Ayyangar JJ. had taken the view that a rule identical in terms with rule 6  f   as it stood till September, 1963 exempted the price of the packing material as well. We are entirely in agreement with the view taken by the learned judges in that case. The charges for packing include both the price of the packing material as well as the labour charges relating to packing.

arguments.claim: Subsequent changes in Rule 6(f) merely clarified the intention

anchor.surface_text: The words in sub. cl.  ii  of rule 6 f  and other such like services in our opinion refer to the word delivery immediately preceding those words. The subsequent changes effected in the rule merely clarified the intention of the rule making authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government orders fixed actual packing charges equivalent to gunny bag price under cl. 6(4); precedents hold wholly controlled price means no sale; contention power only for max price not raised earlier

holdings.text: The charges for packing include both the price of the packing material as well as the labour charges relating to packing

anchor.surface_text: We are entirely in agreement with the view taken by the learned judges in that case. The charges for packing include both the price of the packing material as well as the labour charges relating to packing. The words in sub. cl.  ii  of rule 6 f  and other such like services

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with earlier Madras HC in State of Madras In re; 'charges for packing' covers material and labour; words 'other such like services' refer to delivery

holdings.text: We hold that Damodaran Chettiars case supra was not correctly decided

anchor.surface_text: The subsequent changes effected in the rule merely clarified the intention of the rule making authority. We hold that Damodaran Chettiars case  supra  was number correctly decided. At the hearing a new contention was sought to be raised by Mr. S. T. Desai.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Damodaran overlooked earlier binding HC decision; court prefers earlier interpretation

holdings.text: The subsequent changes effected in the rule merely clarified the intention of the rule making authority

anchor.surface_text: The words in sub. cl.  ii  of rule 6 f  and other such like services in our opinion refer to the word delivery immediately preceding those words. The subsequent changes effected in the rule merely clarified the intention of the rule making authority.
